title: What Color Should You Use for Math? The Debate & Color Theory, Explained

steps.title: Math can be red or blue, depending on your personal associations.
steps.content: Math can be red or blue, depending on your personal associations. There’s no one right answer to the “What color is math?” debate—though people strongly defend their responses on social media. [1] X Research source The way your school or teachers color-coded subjects, the emotional or symbolic associations you have with each color, and your subconscious feelings about the subject of math may influence your answer. The social media debate involves what colors people associate with different school subjects, but is also commonly posed in terms of which color folder they would use for each subject. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Math may be red because red is associated with aggression and intensity.
steps.content: Math may be red because red is associated with aggression and intensity. For many people, math is one of the most challenging subjects, especially in higher education. [3] X Research source Thus, you may think of red when you think of math because you’re remembering the stress and anxiety you felt in difficult math classes. The color red is associated with passion, but also has ties to aggression and stress. [4] X Research source It may also be the case that you happened to use a red notebook, binder, or folder for your math classes as a child, making you subconsciously associate the color with the subject.

steps.title: Math may be blue because blue is associated with serenity and orderliness.
steps.content: Math may be blue because blue is associated with serenity and orderliness. Not everyone struggles with math—and those who enjoy the subject might find a sense of calm in the neat consistency of solving problems. If you find math relaxing and serene, you may associate it with blue because the color evokes the same feelings as the subject for you. [5] X Research source It’s also possible that your teacher color-coded the subject as blue by using blue worksheets and books. Or, you chose to use blue notebooks and folders for the subject, developing a subconscious association between the color and the subject. Beyond color associations, math fans may even see the math formulas in a positive light. One study found that mathematicians’ emotional brain centers—the same area of the brain activated when appreciating beauty in art—were activated by math equations they rated as beautiful. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Besides math, people debate about the colors of English, history, and science.
steps.content: Besides math, people debate about the colors of English, history, and science. The debate usually begins with the premise that the color options are red, yellow (or orange), green, and blue, and the subject options are math, English, history (or social studies), and science. [7] X Research source Many TikToks and X posts debate which color each subject is, but common answers suggest English and math are each red or blue, science is yellow or green, and history is green or orange. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Seeing words as colors could be a sign of grapheme-color synesthesia.
steps.content: Seeing words as colors could be a sign of grapheme-color synesthesia. While not a medical condition, synesthesia describes a phenomenon in which people feel like two unrelated senses are connected—for example, tasting numbers by experiencing a flavor when you see or think of them. Grapheme-color synesthesia is a type of synesthesia in which graphemes (letters, numbers, or symbols) are seen as colors. This phenomenon could explain why some people feel strongly about what color math is. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Want to know if you have synesthesia? Take our quiz to find out!

steps.title: Educators and students color-code subjects to stay organized.
steps.content: Educators and students color-code subjects to stay organized. Teachers considering the “What color is math?” debate may be biased by their own classroom system. Many educators use colorful bins and folders in their classroom to organize tests and assignments for different subjects. [10] X Research source Students also frequently color-code supplies by subject to stay organized and remember which supplies are for which subject. Color-coding is especially helpful for children with learning differences like ADHD. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Internet debates on the color of math date back to 2013.
steps.content: Internet debates on the color of math date back to 2013. However, the debate went viral in 2022, when Twitter user @jackiantonovich asked users which folder colors they’d assign to their school subjects. [12] X Research source The trivial question made its way to national news segments, as anchors and audiences debated if math was red, blue, or another color. [13] X Research source Since 2022, the question, “What color is math?” trends on TikTok occasionally. [14] X Research source
